Real stories of people living under socialism start to take shape in order to assert this position.
The communist regime made Holidays as part of its political agenda.
The seaside development was branded as one of the regime's great achievements in Hallmark of its progressiveness.
Few people knew, however, that there was a financial reward at stake, attracting tourists from the western world entailed a much needed cash inflow.
Moreover, at the height of the Cold War, the race for ideological supremacy architecture was a mighty tool.
The idyllic images of the postcards do not show the actual grim discrimination taking place in the seaside resorts, although claiming Supreme equality.
Not every sector of the population had access to the glamorous resorts, peasantry and the lower working class were excluded by default.

On another level, foreign visitors were benefiting from significantly better services compared to the local tourists, who are often denied access to many bars, shops, restaurants and even hotels reserved for the foreign tourists.
Also, the architectural design was deliberately educational, as the regime was looking to form its supporters in what it called the new man.
The architecture was instrumental in molding the new habitat, exposing people to such an environment would shape them into what the ideal society would.
Or should be?
The ideological aspects aside, there were also very practical considerations.
The hotel rooms were austere and reduced to a minimum so that people would spend time in the open, elaborately designed public spaces where they could be surveilled.

Architecture feeds a lot into the medium of film.
I use different techniques in order to integrate architectural imagery in a time based plot.
Reinterpretation has to do with re framing the meaning of certain elements in a time based plot.

So to sum up, it becomes apparent that architecture was not only a byproduct of a complex ideological narrative, but an active catalyst in shaping the socialist, utopian or more like dystopian vision.
As we had seen.

Secondly, the complexity of this architecture places it in a sort of Gray area while it acted as a propaganda tool and encouraged gruesome discrimination, it also drove the architectural experimentation forward and offer a viable alternative to the urban reality of the time.

And Lastly, the seaside development seemed to have this rather peculiar quality of constantly reflecting the broader political reality around it being dictatorial control or turbulent transition to free market economy.
So what I wanted to achieve with this project is basically to gain a thorough understanding of this architecture and initiate the debate around it in terms of a more informed spatial production.
